Description: Introductory text / welcome, describing the purpose and contents of the tour
Intro to the watershed - central valley and delta, Sacramento and San Joaquin Rivers, etc

Media Credit: Animated overview of the Sacramento River Flood Control System produced by the US Army Corps of Engineers
Description: about the Sacramento River Flood Control System
Zooming in on the Yolo Bypass: 59,000 acres, 92 square miles, fremont weir, sacramento weir, delta

The Pacific Flyway
- YBWA: Restoring a link in the chain of wetlands that provide food and cover for birds traveling the Flyway
Map Credit: Bird migration data courtesy of USGS Western Ecological Research Center, Dixon Field Station. Special thanks to Mike Casazza and Cory Overton.

Description: Historical ecology
Historical ecology, zooming in, habitats present in the Yolo Bypass
Feb 1990: Yolo Basin Working Group sponsors a meeting with area landowners at the California Trucking Association Building in West Sacramento to discuss the proposal for a Yolo Basin Wildlife Area.
Feb 1990: Yolo Basin Foundation founded
Dec 1991: State Wildlife Conservation Board completes purchase of approximately 3100 acres at the Putah Creek Sinks from PG&E Properties, Inc. for $4.57 million. - Funded by 1988 Proposition 70
Location: show the putah ck sinks overlay

Description: Apr 1992: Final Environmental Assessment/Project Modification Report for Yolo Basin Wetlands project is released by U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. (opportunity for overlay?) 17 Aug 1995: Ground Breaking Celebration is held at Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area. Over 150 people attend morning ceremonies.
Nov 1993: Comprehensive resource inventory completed. (opportunity for overlay?)
Feb 1994 First duck days held
17 Aug 1995: Ground Breaking Celebration is held at Yolo Bypass Wildlife Area. Over 150 people attend morning ceremonies.
Nov 1995 First phase of construction completed - 400 acres of ponds in NW section and 400 acres of ponds in SW section. Pintails are observed the next month during christmas bird coutn.

15 Nov 1997: President Clinton, Congressman Vic Fazio, John Garamendi, Assistant Deputy Director of US Dept. of the Interior, John Zhirsky, Assistant Secretary of Civil Works for US Army Corps of Engineers, Doug Wheeler, Secretary of State Resources Agency, Richard Rominger, Assistant Secretary of US Dept. of Agriculture and 800 other supporters attended a rainy but festive opening celebration of the completion of the Yolo Basin Wetlands Project and the transfer of the YBWA from the Corps of Engineers to State Dept. of Fish and Game.
Aug 1998: Demonstration Wetland irrigation is installed and 400 trees planted. First flood up of demonstration wetlands occurs.
Dec 2001: Purchase of 12,000 additional acres including the Causeway Ranch, Los Rios Farms properties, Giverson Ranch and Tule Ranch, expanding the Wildlife Area to 16,000 acres.
intro to management section, multi-benefits etc

Permanent ponds, 4-5' deep - year-round habitat for resident waterfowl 
- supports summer nesting waterfowl (coots, mallards, gadwalls, cinnamon teal)

Seasonal wetlands October thru April, 6-18" deep
- tule and cattails
- flooded starting sept/oct to provide wintering habitat for large numbers migratory waterfowl

Seasonal wetlands are drained in April before invasive weeds can establish (first partial drain to provide shallow shorebird habitat - confirm)
- regrading/restoration/re-seeding/irrigation in the summer
Shallow shorebird ponds are flooded in July (S) - August (N) to provide foraging area
Putah Creek - flows in from lake berryessa/solano, riparian corridor, etc.
Riparian woodland - cottonwood, willow, oregon ash, box elder, blue elderberry
Agriculture - rice harvest - 2400 ac

Agriculture - post harvest flooding
- starting November, drained in March as migratory waterfowl/shorebirds begin to head north
Agriculture - other crops - tomatoes, sunflower, safflower, corn, milo
Agriculture - rangelands - 5000 ac irrigated/dryland pasture

Rangeland: wildflowers: 
- vernal pools characteristic rings of goldfields, miniature lupine, butter-and-eggs, dowingia, monkey flower, tidy tips
Land use mosaic with trails, roads, parking lots
winter viewing opportunities by car - popular one-way auto loop
winter viewing opportunities on foot - get out of the car at Parking Lot C and take the loop along the Tule Trail to see seasonal wetlands to the west and permanent ponds to the east

hunting opportunities
- duck hunting season begins in October and extends through january
- pheasant season mid-Nov

additional public access off-season - starting in February, catch the tail end of the migratory waterfowl season, and the bountiful shorebird display in the spring. These trails are open until hunting begins in October
* photo of Green's Lake?
Education: demonstration wetlands as start of field trips to the wildlife area and other local destinations like grasslands
Discover the Flyway - 60000 students in first decade 1997-2017
Bats under the flyway
Glide tule ranch vernal pool and wildflower tours
Engagement with the arts

Chapter: Get to know the birds and seasons
Description: Introduction to birds/seasons section - what and when, from winter migratory ducks/geese, spring shorebirds, summer nesters

winter - see spectacular numbers of wintering waterfowl:
- most common: northern pintail, northern shoveler; 
- also look for: american widgeon, green-winged teal, canvasback, common goldeneye, bufflehead
- pintail arrive as early as august. Most arrive in october, peak in December, and head north again come March/April
Map Credit: Bird migration data courtesy of USGS Western Ecological Research Center, Dixon Field Station. Special thanks to Mike Casazza and Cory Overton.

Description: anserines tending to arrive in November: snow geese and greater white-fronted geese (10K+/season) also ross's goose, tundra swan
Map Credit: Bird migration data courtesy of USGS Western Ecological Research Center, Dixon Field Station. Special thanks to Mike Casazza and Cory Overton.

Description: year-round waterfowl - summer nesting: coot, mallard, gadwall, cinnamon teal (and some shovelers). Look for broods of ducklings in may through july
also year-round: great blue herons, great egrets, snowy egrets, white pelicans,
summer waders in the freshwater marsh: white-faced ibis (nest in the tule marsh, forage in the rice fields), least bittern

shorebirds:
- year-round: avocets, black-necked stilts, killdeer, coots nest in the wildlife area in April, chicks in May
- others such as black-bellied plovers, greater yellowlegs , long-billed dowitchers head north in April to nest, returning to the wildlife area mid-summer
- phalaropes, willets, godwits, and some sandpipers stop by in the spring and late fall, a stop on their migration to their northern summer breeding grounds
Map Credit: Bird migration data courtesy of USGS Western Ecological Research Center, Dixon Field Station. Special thanks to Mike Casazza and Cory Overton.

Description: look among the wetland vegetation for red-winged blackbird, marsh wren, and rarer birds like the sora
grasslands ecosystem: western meadowlark, yellow-billed magpie, tree swallows

raptors: red-tailed hawk, swainson's hawk, northern harrier
- swainson's hawks arrive from the South in April to nest, staying through September
- look for great horned owls in the trees
Map Credit: Bird migration data courtesy of USGS Western Ecological Research Center, Dixon Field Station. Special thanks to Mike Casazza and Cory Overton.

Description: salmon: Putah Creek Flashboard Dam removed in december to facilitate salmon run
ecosystem restoration program grant - putah creek salmon passage
project nigiri / floodplain salmon
